lines.value: computers may directly model the problem being solved in the sense that the problem being solved is mapped as closely as possible onto the physical phenomena being exploited
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example electron flows might be used to model the flow of water in a dam
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such analog computers were once common in the 1960s but are now rare
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most computers today the problem is translated into mathematical terms then reduced to simple boolean algebra
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: electronic circuits are then used to represent boolean operations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since almost all of mathematics can be reduced to boolean operations a sufficiently fast electronic computer is capable of attacking the majority of mathematical problems and much much more
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this basic idea which made modern digital computers possible was formally identified and explored by claude e shannon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers cannot solve all mathematical problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: alan turing identified which problems could and could not be solved by computers and in doing so founded theoretical computer science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the oed2 lists the year 1897 as the first year the word was used to refer to a mechanical calculating device
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by 1946 several qualifiers were introduced by the oed2 to differentiate between the different types of machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these qualifiers included analogue digital and electronic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however from the context of the citation it is obvious these terms were in use prior to 1946
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tempo entri wiktionary pikeun kecap pikeun definisi tarjamah jeung rincian )
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the complexities involved in classifying the various types of computer are compounded by the exponential growth in computing capacity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: roughly speaking computing devices have doubled in capacity instructions processed per second per $1000 every 18 to 24 months since 1900
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gordon e moore co founder of intel first described this property of computer development in 1965 see moore's law
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the exponential growth in capacity has been sustained by the rapid evolution of engineering techniques used to build computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hand in hand with this increase in capacity per unit cost has been an equally dramatic process of
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first electronic computers such as the eniac announced in 1946 were huge devices that weighed tons occupied entire rooms and required many operators to function successfully
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they were so expensive that only governments and large research organizations could afford them and were considered so exotic that only a handful would ever be required to satisfy global demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by contrast modern computers are orders of magnitude more powerful less expensive smaller and have become
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to define what a computer is it is necessary to develop a classification of computing devices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following sections describe several different approaches to classifying computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these classification approaches must be used in combination to unambiguously describe a given machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most obvious way to classify computing machines is by their usage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this approach is commonly employed by manufacturers of computers to describe their products and users of computers to describe the machines they interact with
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a less ambiguous approach for classifying computing machines is by their implementation technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earliest computers were purely mechanical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1930s electro mechanical components relays were introduced from the telecommunications industry and in the 1940s the first purely electronic computers were constructed from thermionic valves tubes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1950s and 1960s valves were gradually replaced with transistors and in the late 1960s and early 1970s semiconductor integrated circuits silicon chips were adopted and have been the mainstay of computing technology ever since
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this description of implementation technologies is not exhaustive it only covers the mainstream of development
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically many exotic technologies have been explored and abandoned
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example economic models have been constructed using water flowing through multiple constricted channels and between 1903 and 1909 percy e ludgate developed a design for a programmable analytical machine based weaving technologies in which variables were carried in shuttles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: efforts are currently underway to develop optical computers that use light rather than electricity and the possibility that dna can be used for computing is being explored
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one radical new area of research that could lead to computers with dramatic new capabilities is the field of quantum computing but this is presently in its early experimental stages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the exception of quantum computers the implementation technology of a computer is not as important for classification purposes as the features that the machine implements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern computers combine many fundamental design features that have been developed by various contributors over many years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these features are often independent of implementation technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern computers derive their overall capabilities from the way these features interact
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the most important design features are listed below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a fundamental decision in designing a computer is whether it should be digital or analog
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: digital computers process discrete numeric or symbolic values while analog computers process continuous data signals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the 1940s digital computers have become by far the most common although analog computers are still used for some specialized purposes such as robotics and cyclotron control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other approaches such as pulse computing and quantum computing are possible but are either used for special purposes or are still experimental
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a significant design development in digital computing was the introduction of binary as the internal numeral system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this removed the need for complex carry mechanisms required for computers based on other numeral systems such as the decimal system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the adoption of binary resulted in simplified designs for implementing arithmetic functions and logic operations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ability to program a computer provide it with a set of instructions for execution without physically reconfiguring the machine is a fundamental design feature of most computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this feature was significantly extended when machines were developed that could control the flow of execution of the program
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this allowed computers to control the order in which the program of instructions was executed based on data calculated by the program as it executed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this major design advance was dramatically simplified by the introduction of binary arithmetic which can be used to represent various logic operations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the course of a calculation it is often necessary to store intermediate values for use in later calculations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the performance of many computers is largely dictated by the speed with which they can read and write values to and from this memory and the overall capacity of the memory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally memory was used only for intermediate values but in the 1940s it was suggested that the program itself could be stored in this way
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this advance led to the development of the first stored program computers of the type used today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps the best way to classify the various types of computing device is by their intrinsic capabilities rather than their usage implementation technology or design features
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers can be subdivided into three main types based on capability single purpose devices that can compute only one function e.g the antikythera mechanism 87 bc and lord kelvin's tide predictor 1876 special purpose devices that can compute a limited range of functions e.g charles babbage's difference engine no 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 1832 and vannevar bush's differential analyser 1932 and general purpose devices of the type used today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically the word computer has been used to describe all these types of machine but modern colloquial usage usually restricts the term to general purpose machines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by definition a general purpose computer can solve any problem that can be expressed as a program and executed within the practical limits set by the storage capacity of the computer the size of program the speed of program execution and the reliability of the machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1934 alan turing proved that given the right program any general purpose computer could emulate the behavior of any other computer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this mathematical proof was purely as no general purpose computers existed at the time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the implications of this proof are profound for example any existing general purpose computer is theoretically able to emulate albeit slowly any general purpose computer that may be built in the future
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers with general purpose capabilities are called turing complete and this status is often used as the capability that defines modern computers however this definition is
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several computing devices with simplistic designs have been shown to be turing complete
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the z3 developed by konrad zuse in 1941 is the earliest working computer that has been shown to be turing complete so far the proof was developed in 1998
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the z3 and possibly other early devices may be theoretically turing complete they are impractical as general purpose computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they lie in what is humorously known as the turing tar pit a place where anything is possible but nothing of interest is practical see the jargon file
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern computers are more than theoretically general purpose they are also practical general purpose tools
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the modern digital electronic general purpose computer was developed by many contributors over an extended period from the mid 1930s to the late 1940s during this period many experimental machines were built that were possibly turing complete abc eniac harvard mk i colossus etc see the history of computing hardware
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all these machines have been claimed at one time or another as the first computer but they all had limited utility as general purpose problem solving devices and their designs have been discarded
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the late 1940s the first design for a stored program computer was developed and documented see the first draft at the moore school of electrical engineering at the university of pennsylvania
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the approach described by this document has become known as the von neumann architecture after it's only named author jon von neumann although others at the moore school essentially invented the design
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the von neumann architecture solved problems inherent in the design of the eniac which was then under construction by storing the machines program in it's own memory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: von neumann made the design available to other researchers shortly after the eniac was annouced in 1946
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plans were developed to implemented the design at the moore school in a machine called the edvac
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the edvac was not operational until 1953 due to technical difficulties in implementing a reliable memory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other research institutes who had obtained copies of the design solved the considerable technical problems of implimenting a working memory before the moore school team and implemented their own stored program computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in order of first successful operation the first 5 stored program computers that implemented the main features of the von neumann architecture were to be precise most modern computers are binary electronic stored program general purpose computing devices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the special purpose computers that were popular in the 1930s and early 1940s have not been completely replaced by general purpose computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the cost and size of computers has fallen and their capabilities have increased it has become cost effective to use them for special purpose applications
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many domestic and industrial devices including mobile telephones video recorders automotive ignition systems etc now contain special purpose computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cases these computers are turing complete video games pdas but many are programmed once in the factory and only seldom if ever reprogrammed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the program that these devices execute is often contained in a read only memory rom chip which would need to be replaced to change the operation of the machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers embedded inside other devices are commonly referred to as microcontrollers or embedded computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: single purpose computers were the earliest form of computing device
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: given some inputs they could calculate the result of the single function that was implemented by their mechanism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: general purpose computers have almost completely replaced single purpose computers and in doing so have created a completely new field of human endeavor software development
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: general purpose computers must be programmed with a set of instructions specific to the task they are required to perform and these instructions are collectively know as computer software
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the design of single purpose computing devices and many special purpose computing devices is now a conceptual exercise that consists solely of designing software
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers may be classified according to the way they are operated by the users
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two main types exist batch processing and interactive processing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first electronic digital computers with their large size and cost mainly performed scientific calculations often to support military objectives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the eniac was originally designed to calculate ballistics firing tables for artillery but it was also used to calculate neutron cross sectional densities to see if the hydrogen bomb would work properly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this calculation performed in december 1945 through january 1946 and involving over a million punch cards of data showed the design then under consideration would fail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly many of the most powerful supercomputers available today are also used for nuclear weapons simulations the csir mk i the first australian stored program computer evaluated rainfall patterns for the catchment area of the snowy mountains scheme a large hydroelectric generation project
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others were used in cryptanalysis for example the world's first programmable though not general purpose digital electronic computer colossus built during world war ii
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite this early focus of scientific applications computers were quickly used in other areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from the beginning stored program computers were applied to business problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the leo a stored program computer built by j lyons and co in britain was operational and being used for inventory management and other purposes 3 years before ibm built their first commercial stored program computer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: continual reductions in the cost and size of computers saw them adopted by ever smaller organizations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and with the invention of the microprocessor in the 1970s it became possible to produce inexpensive computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1980s personal computers became popular for many tasks including book keeping writing and printing documents calculating forecasts and other repetitive mathematical tasks involving spreadsheets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1970s computer engineers at various research institutions throughout the us began to link their computers together using telecommunications technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this effort was funded by arpa and the computer network that it produced was called the arpanet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the technologies that made the arpanet possible rapidly spread and evolved
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in time the network spread beyond academic institutions and became known as the internet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1990s the development of world wide web technologies enabled ordinary non technical people to use the internet and it grew rapidly to become a communications medium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the technologies used in computers have changed dramatically since the first electronic general purpose computers of the 1940s see history of computing hardware for more details most still use the von neumann architecture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the von neumann architecture describes a computer with four main sections the arithmetic and logic unit alu the control circuitry the memory and the input and output devices collectively termed i/o
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these parts are interconnected by a bundle of wires a bus and are usually driven by a timer or clock although other events could drive the control circuitry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this system memory is a sequence of numbered cells each containing a small piece of information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the information may be an instruction to tell the computer what to do
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cell may contain data that the computer needs to perform the instruction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: any cell may contain either and indeed what is at one time data might be instructions later
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general the contents of a memory cell can be changed at any time it is a scratchpad rather than a stone tablet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the size of each cell and the number of cells varies greatly from computer to computer and the technologies used to implement memory have varied greatly from electromechanical relays to mercury filled tubes and later springs in which acoustic pulses were formed to matrices of permanent magnets to individual transistors to integrated circuits with millions of capacitors on a single chip
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the arithmetic and logical unit or alu is the device that performs elementary operations such as arithmetic operations addition subtraction and so on logical operations and or not and comparison operations for example comparing the contents of two bytes for equality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this unit is where the real work is done
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the control unit keeps track of which bytes in memory contain the current instruction that the computer is performing telling the alu what operation to perform and retrieving the information from memory that it needs to perform it and transfers the result back to the appropriate memory location
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once that occurs the control unit goes to the next instruction typically located in the next slot memory address unless the instruction is a jump instruction informing the computer that the next instruction is located in another location
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when referrring to memory the current instruction may use various addressing modes to determine the relevant address in memory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today there are mainly two kinds of cpu's available for home use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first is made by intel the cpu giant and the other is made by amd(their main competition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the past motorollaand cyrix have also manufactured cpu's for desktop use but intel pentium & celeron and amd athlon opteron 64 have proven themselves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the i/o allows the computer to obtain information from the outside world and send the results of its work back there
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is an incredibly broad range of i/o devices from the familiar keyboards monitors and floppy disk drives to the more unusual such as webcams
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what all input devices have in common is that they encode convert information of some type into data which can further be processed by the digital computer system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: output devices on the other hand decode the data into information which can be understood by the computer user
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this sense a digital computer system is an example of a data processing system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the machine set of instructions are not the rich instructions of a human language
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a computer only has a limited number of well defined simple instructions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers can perform two tasks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they can count and they can compare
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typical sorts of instructions supported by most computers are copy the contents of cell 123 and place the copy in cell 456 add the contents of cell 666 to cell 042 and place the result in cell 013 if the contents of cell 999 are 0 your next instruction is at cell 345
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instructions are represented within the computer as binary code a base two system of counting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the code for copy might be 001 for example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the particular instruction set that a specific computer supports is known as that computer's machine language
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in practice people do not normally write the instructions for computers directly in machine language but rather use a high level programming language which is then translated into the machine language automatically by special computer programs interpreters and compilers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some programming languages map very closely to the machine language such as assembler low level languages at the other end languages like prolog are based on abstract principles far removed from the details of the machine's actual operation high level languages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contemporary computers put the alu and control unit into a single integrated circuit known as the central processing unit or cpu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically the computer's memory is located on a few small integrated circuits near the cpu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the overwhelming majority of the computer's mass is either ancillary systems for instance to supply electrical power or i/o devices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some larger computers differ from the above model in one major respect they have multiple cpus and control units working simultaneously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: additionally a few computers used mainly for research purposes and scientific computing have differed significantly from the above model but they have found little commercial application because their programming model has not yet standardized
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the functioning of a computer is therefore in principle quite straightforward
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically on each clock cycle the computer fetches instructions and data from its memory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the instructions are executed the results are stored and the next instruction is fetched
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this procedure repeats until a halt instruction is encountered
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computer programs are simply large lists of instructions for the computer to execute perhaps with tables of data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many computer programs contain millions of instructions and many of those instructions are executed repeatedly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a typical modern pc in the year 2003 can execute around 2-3 billion instructions per second
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers do not gain their extraordinary capabilities through the ability to execute complex instructions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rather they do millions of simple instructions arranged by clever people programmers good programmers develop sets of instructions to do common tasks for instance draw a dot on screen and then make those sets of instructions available to other programmers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nowadays most computers appear to execute several programs at the same time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is usually referred to as multitasking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in reality the cpu executes instructions from one program then after a short period of time it switches to a second program and executes some of its instructions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this small interval of time is often referred to as a time slice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this creates the illusion of multiple programs being executed simultaneously by sharing the cpu's time between the programs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is similar to how a movie is simply a rapid succession of still frames
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the operating system is the program that usually controls this time sharing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: komputer salawasna butuh sahanteuna hiji program nu salawasna jalan sangkang operasina jalan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina operasi normal program ieu katelah sistim operasi ing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: operating system os
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sistim operasi nangtukeun program mana nu jalan iraha jeung sumberdaya naon kayaning memori atawa i/o nu kudu dipake
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the operating system also provides a layer of abstraction over the hardware and gives access by providing services to other programs such as code drivers which allow programmers to write programs for a machine without needing to know the intimate details of all attached electronic devices.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following important properties of the square root functions are valid for all positive real numbers x and y fungsi akar kuadrat umumna metakeun wilangan rasional ka wilangan aljabar √x is rational if and only if x is a rational number which after cancelling is a fraction of two perfect squares
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in particular √2 is irrational
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in geometrical terms the square root function maps the area of a square to its side length
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose that x and a are reals and that x 2 =a and we want to find x a common mistake is to take the square root and deduce that x = √a
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is incorrect because the square root of x 2 is not x but the absolute value |x| one of our above rules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus all we can conclude is that |x| = √a or equivalently x = ±√a
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in calculus for instance when proving that the square root function is continuous or differentiable or when computing certain limits the following identity often comes handy its taylor series about x = 1 can be found using the binomial theorem the same identity is exploited when computing square roots with logarithm tables or slide rules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a commonly used algorithm for approximating √x is known as the babylonian method and is based on newton's method
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it proceeds as follows this algorithm works equally well in the p adic numbers but cannot be used to identify real square roots with p adic square roots it is easy for example to construct a sequence of rational numbers by this method which converges to +3 in the reals but to -3 in the 2-adics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this method while much slower than the babylonian method has the advantage that it is exact if the given number has a square root whose decimal representation terminates then the algorithm terminates and produces the correct square root after finitely many steps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can thus be used to check whether a given integer is a square number
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: write the number in decimal and divide it into pairs of digits starting from the decimal point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the numbers are laid out similar to the long division algorithm and the final square root will appear above the original number
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for each iteration x 01 1*1=1 1 2x 00 44 22*2=44 2 24x 07 29 243*3=729 3 246x 98 56 2464*4=9856 4 00 00 algorithm terminates answer is 12.34 although demonstrated here for base 10 numbers the procedure works for any base including base 2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the description above 20 means double the number base used in the case of binary this would really be 100
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the algorithm is in fact much easier to perform in base 2 as in every step only the two digits 0 and 1 have to be tested
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see shifting nth root algorithm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pell's equation yields a method for finding rational approximations of square roots of integers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: based on pell's equation there is a methode to calculate the square root in the head by simply subtraction of odd numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ex square root of 27 is 5 11-9 = 2 first number is 5 2 x 100 = 200 and 5 x 20 + 1 = 101 1 200-101 = 99 next number is 1 99 x 100 = 9900 and 51 x 20 + 1 = 1021 9 1676-1037 = 639 next number is 9 the result gives us 5.19 as the square root of 27
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: quadratic irrationals that is numbers involving square roots in the form a+√b)/c have periodic continued fractions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this makes them easy to calculate recursively given the period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example to calculate √2 we make use of the fact that √2-1 = [0;22,22,2,...] and use the recurrence relation : a n+1 =1/(2+a n ) with a 0 =0 to obtain √2-1 to some specific precision specified through n levels of recurrence and add 1 to the result to obtain √2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to every non zero complex number z there exist precisely two numbers w such that w 2 = z the usual definition of √z is as follows if z = r exp(iφ is represented in polar coordinates with n < φ ≤ n then we set √z = √r exp(iφ/2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus defined the square root function is holomorphic everywhere except on the non positive real numbers where it isn't even continuous
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the above taylor series for √(1+x remains valid for complex numbers x with |x| < 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the number is in rectangular form the following formula can be used the third equality cannot be justified
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see invalid proof however the law can only be wrong up to a factor -1 √(zw = ±√(z)√(w is true for either ± as + or as but not both at the same time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that √(c 2 ) = ±c therefore √(a 2 b 2 ) = ±ab and therefore √(zw = ±√(z)√(w using a = √(z and b = √(w
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if a is a positive definite matrix or operator then there exists precisely one positive definite matrix or operator b with b 2 = a we then define √a = b more generally to every normal matrix or operator a there exist normal operators b such that b 2 = a in general there are several such operators b for every a and the square root function cannot be defined for normal operators in a satisfactory manner
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: positive definite operators are akin to positive real numbers and normal operators are akin to complex numbers

lines.value: false positives are a problem in any kind of test no test is perfect and sometimes the test will incorrectly report a positive result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if a test for a particular disease is performed on a patient then there is a chance usually small that the test will return a positive result even if the patient does not have the disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the problem lies however not just in the chance of a false positive prior to testing but determining the chance that a positive result is in fact a false positive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as we will demonstrate using bayes theorem if a condition is rare then the majority of positive results may be false positives even if the test for that condition is otherwise reasonably accurate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose that a test for a particular disease has a very high success rate let a be the event that the patient has the disease and b be the event that the test returns a positive result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then using the second alternative form of bayes theorem above the probability of a true positive is and hence the probability of a false positive is about 1 &minus 0.019 = 0.981
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the apparent high accuracy of the test the incidence of the disease is so low one in a thousand that the vast majority of patients who test positive 98 in a hundred do not have the disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nonetheless this is 20 times the proportion before we knew the outcome of the test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the test is not useless and retesting may improve the reliability of the result in particular a test must be very reliable in reporting a negative result when the patient does not have the disease if it is to avoid the problem of false positives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in mathematical terms this would ensure that the second term in the denominator of the above calculation is small relative to the first term
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if the test reported a negative result in patients without the disease with probability 0.999 then using this value in the calculation yields a probability of a false positive of roughly 0.5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this example bayes theorem helps show that the accuracy of tests for rare conditions must be very high in order to produce reliable results from a single test due to the possibility of false positives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the probability of a false negative could also be calculated using bayes theorem to completely characterise the possible errors in the test results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bayesian inference can be used to coherently assess additional evidence of guilt in a court setting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :p(g | e = p(g p(e | g p(e)suppose on the basis of other evidence a juror decides that there is a 30% chance that the defendent is guilty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose also that the forensic evidence is that the probability that a person chosen at random would have dna that matched that at the crime scene was 1 in a million or 10 −6
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the event e can occur in two ways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: either the defendent is guilty with prior probability 0.3 and thus his dna is present with probability 1 or he is innocent with prior probability 0.7 and he is unlucky enough to be one of the 1 in a million matching people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the juror could coherently revise his opinion to take into account the dna evidence as follows :p(g | e = 0.3 &times 1.0 0.3 &times 1.0 + 0.7 &times 10 -6 ) = 0.99999766667
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in may 1968 the us nuclear submarine scorpion ssn 589 failed to arrive as expected at her home port of norfolk virginia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the us navy was convinced that the vessel had been lost off the eastern seabord but an extensive search failed to discover the wreck
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the us navy's deep water expert john craven believed that it was elsewhere and he organised a search south west of the azores based on a controversial approximate triangulation by hydrophones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was allocated only a single ship the usns mizar and he took advice from a firm of consultant mathematicians in order to maximise his resources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a bayesian search methodology was adopted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: experienced submarine commanders were interviewed to construct hypotheses about what could have caused the loss of the scorpion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sea area was divided up into grid squares and a probability assigned to each square under each of the hypotheses to give a number of probability grids one for each hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these were then added together to produce an overall probability grid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the probability attached to each square was then the probability that the wreck was in that square
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a second grid was constructed with probabilities that represented the probability of successfully finding the wreck if that square were to be searched and the wreck were to be actually there
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was a known function of water depth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the result of combining this grid with the previous grid is a grid which gives the probability of finding the wreck in each grid square of the sea if it were to be searched
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this sea grid was systematically searched in a manner which started with the high probability regions first and worked down to the low probability regions last
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each time a grid square was searched and found to be empty its probability was reassessed using bayes theorem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this then forced the probabilities of all the other grid squares to be reassessed upwards also by bayes theorem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the use of this approach was a major computational challenge for the time but it was eventually successful and the scorpion was found in october of that year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose a grid square has a probability p of containing the wreck and that the probability of successfully detecting the wreck if it is there is q if the square is searched and no wreck is found then by bayes the revised probability of the wreck being in the square is given by
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one well known trait of some species of squirrel is the gathering and storing of nuts for the winter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these squirrels are scatter hoarders i.e they will gather nuts and store them in any accessible hiding place usually by burying them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recent research shows that they have excellent memories for the locations of these caches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another characteristic trait of several types of squirrels especially ground squirrels is their tendency to rise on their hind legs and curl their paws flat against their chests when they sense any kind of danger
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they will then survey their surrounding territories
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if they feel that they are in peril they will often send the warning call a loud screeching sound to alert other squirrels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then there is a mad rush to the burrow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unlike rabbits or deer squirrels cannot digest cellulose and must rely on foods rich in protein carbohydrates and fat
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early spring is the hardest time of year for squirrels as buried nuts begin to sprout and are no longer available but new food sources have not become available yet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during these times squirrels rely heavily on the buds of trees in particular those of the silver maple
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the popular impression squirrels are actually omnivores as well as eating a wide variety of plant food including nuts seeds fruits fungi for example mushrooms and green vegetation they also eat insects eggs and even small birds smaller mammals and frogs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also a common occurrence that these foods replace nuts in some of the tropics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there has even been a report of squirrels eating dogs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels are generally clever and persistent animals in residential neighborhoods they are notorious for eating out of bird feeders digging in potted plants either to bury or recover seeds and for setting up house in sheltered areas including attics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while many companies sell bird feeders which are supposedly squirrel proof most of them in fact are not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels are sometimes also pests because they chew on various edible and inedible objects the habit helps keep the squirrel's teeth sharp and also wears them down many rodents teeth grow continuously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: homeowners in areas with a heavy squirrel population must keep attics and basements carefully sealed to prevent property damage caused by nesting squirrels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some homeowners resort to more humane ways of dealing with this such as collecting and planting fur from pets e.g domestic cats and dogs in attics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this fur will indicate to nesting squirrels that a potential predator roams and will encourage evacuation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fake owls and scarecrows are generally ignored by the animals and the best way to prevent chewing on an object is to coat it with something to make it undesirable for instance a soft cloth or chile pepper paste or powder
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrel trapping is also practiced to remove them from residential areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels can be trained to be hand fed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because they are able to cache surplus food they will take as much food as you put out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if a person starts to feed one that squirrel will come back day after day to get its food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels living in parks and campuses in cities have learned long ago that humans are typically a ready source of food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hand feeding is not recommended however because squirrels may carry plague or other animal borne diseases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even if they do not carry disease they often have a hard time telling fingertips from food and bites are painful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels are often the cause of electricity outages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the animals will enter transformers or capacitors looking for food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the squirrels are then electrocuted and cause a power surge that shorts equipment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrels have brought down the high tech nasdaq stock market twice and were responsible for a spate of power outages at the university of alabama
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they will often chew on tree branches to sharpen their teeth but cannot tell the difference between a tree branch and a live power line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rubber plates are sometimes used to prevent access to these facilities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrel meat until recent times was considered a favored meat in certain regions of the united states where it can be listed as wild game
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is evidenced by extensive recipes for its preparation found in cookbooks including the joy of cooking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: squirrel meat can easily be exchanged for rabbit or chicken in recipes with its light red or pink flesh which has only a slight game taste.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polimer nyaeta istilah generik nu dipake pikeun ngadadarkeun molekul panjang
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: molekul panjang ieu diwangun ku unit struktural jeung unit ulangan nu kasambung ku beungkeut kimia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: proses ngarobah unit unit ieu jadi polimer disebut polimerisasi sedengkeun unit unitna disebut monomer nu biasana molekul leutik nu mibanda beurat molekul handap
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monomerna bisa bae sarua atawa mun teu sarua aya gugus kimia nu beda
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beda antarmonomer ieu bisa mangaruhan pasipatanana kayaning kaleyuran a these differences between monomers can affect properties such as solubility flexibility or strength
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in proteins these differences can give the polymer the ability to preferentially adopt one conformation over another as opposed to adopting a random coil see self assembly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although most polymers are organic based on carbon chains there are also inorganic polymers mainly based on a silicon backbone
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term polymer covers a large diverse group of molecules including substances from proteins to high strength kevlar fibres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a key feature that distinguishes polymers from other large molecules is the repetition of units of atoms monomers in their chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this occurs during polymerization in which many monomer molecules link to each other
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the formation of polyethene also called polyethylene involves thousands of ethene molecules bonding together to form a chain of repeating ch 2 units polymers are often named in terms of their monomer units for example polyethylene is represented by because polymers are distinguished by their constituent monomers polymer chains within a substance are often not of equal length
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is unlike other molecules in which every atom is acounted for each molecule having a set molecular mass
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: differing chain lengths occur because polymer chains terminate during polymerization after random intervals of chain lengthening propagation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: proteins are polymers of amino acids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from a dozen to some hundred of the about twenty different monomers form the chain the sequence of monomers determining the shape and activity of the final protein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but there are active regions surrounded by as is believed now aug 2003 structural regions whose sole role is to expose the active region(s there may be more than one on a given protein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so the absolute sequence of amino acids is not important as long as the active regions are expressed being accessible from the outside properly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also whereas the formation of polyethylene occurs spontaneously given the right conditions the manufacture of biopolymers such as proteins and nucleic acids requires the help of catalysts substances that facilitate or accelerate reactions since the 1950s catalysts have also revolutionised the development of synthetic polymers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by allowing more careful control over polymerization reactions polymers with new properties such as the ability to emit coloured light have been manufactured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the well characterization of a polymer requires several parameters which need to be described
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is because a polymer actually consists of a distribution of chains of varying lengths and each chain consists of monomer residues which affect its properties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of these parameters are described below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: physical properties of polymers include degree of polymerization and molar mass distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the propagation of polymer chains branching can occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in radical polymerization this is when a chain curls back and bonds to an earlier part of the chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when this curl breaks it leaves small chains sprouting from the main carbon backbone
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: branched carbon chains cannot line up as close to each other as unbranched chains can
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this causes less contact between atoms of different chains and fewer opportunities for induced or permanent dipoles to occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a low density results from the chains being further apart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lower melting points and tensile strengths are evident because the intermolecular bonds are weaker and require less energy to break
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: stereoregularity or tacticity describes the isomeric arrangement of functional groups on the backbone of carbon chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: isotactic chains are defined as having substituent groups aligned in one direction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this enables them to line up close to each other creating crystalline areas and resulting in highly rigid polymers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast atactic chains have randomly aligned substituent groups
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the chains do not fit together well and the intermolecular forces are low
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this leads to a low density and tensile strength but a high degree of flexibility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: syndiotactic substituent groups alternate regularly in opposite directions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because of this regularity syndiotactic chains can position themselves close to each though not as close as isotactic polymers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: syndiotactic polymers have better impact strength than isotactic polymers because of the higher flexibility resulting from their weaker intermolecular forces
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: copolymerization is polymerization with two or more different monomers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: already mentioned are the twenty amino acid monomers that make up protein chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: copolymerization of different monomers can result in varied properties of polymers just as different amino acids result in different shapes of proteins
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example copolymerising ethene with small amounts of hex 1 ene is one way to form linear low density polyethene lldpe see polyethylene
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the c 4 branches resulting from the hexene lower the density and prevent such large crystalline regions within the polymer as in hdpe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that lldpe can withstand strong tearing forces whilst remaining flexible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following image shows a specific type of copolymerization called a step growth polymerization or condensation polymerization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this particular polymerization a small molecule is released upon polymerization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the following reaction scheme water is given off and nylon is formed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the type of nylon name and properties are governed by the r and r groups in the monomers used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the attractive forces between polymer chains play a large part in determining a polymer's properties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because polymer chains are so long these interchain forces are amplified far beyond the attractions between conventional molecules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also longer chains are more amorphous randomly oriented
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polymers can be visualised as tangled spaghetti chains pulling any one spaghetti strand out is a lot harder the more tangled the chains are
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these stronger forces typically result in high tensile strength and melting points
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the intermolecular forces in polymers are determined by dipoles in the monomer units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polymers containing amide groups can form hydrogen bonds between adjacent chains the positive hydrogen atoms in n h groups of one chain are strongly attracted to the oxygen atoms in c=o groups on another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these strong hydrogen bonds result in for example the high tensile strength and melting point of kevlar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polyesters have dipole dipole bonding between the oxygen atoms in c=o groups and the hydrogens in h c groups
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dipole bonding is not as strong as hydrogen bonding so ethene's melting point and strength are lower than kevlar's but polyesters have greater flexibility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethene however has no permanent dipole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the attractive forces between polyethylene chains arise from weak van der waals forces
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: molecules can be thought of as being surrounded by a cloud of negative electrons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as two polymer chains approach their electron clouds repel one another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has the effect of lowering the electron density on one side of a polymer chain creating a slight positive dipole on this side
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this charge is enough to actually attract the second polymer chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: van der waals forces are quite weak however so polyethene melts at low temperatures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a variety of laboratory techniques are used to determine the properties of polymers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: techniques such as wide angle xray scattering small angle xray scattering and small angle neutron scattering are used to determine the crystalline structure of polymers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gel permeation chromatography is used to determine the number average molecular weight weight average molecular weight and polydispersity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ftir is used to determine composition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thermal properties such as the glass transition temperature and melting point can be determined by differential scanning calorimetry and dynamic mechanical analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thermal degradation followed by analysis of the fragments is one more technique for determining the possible structure of the polymer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polymer known as polymer substrate is used for everyday banknotes in australia and new zealand and is also used in commemorative notes in other countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also polymerization biopolymer condensation polymer addition polymer synthetic polymer glass transition temperature important publications in polymer chemistry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina basa sapopoe internet kadang nujul ka layanan world wide web surat elektronik jeung ngobrol online nu aya na internet

lines.value: artikel utama sajarah internet ngacambahna bibit internet dimimitian dina taun 1969 ku ayana arpanet nu diwangun ku advanced research projects agency arpa departemen pertahanan amerika sarikat
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sababaraha panalungtikan munggaran nu nyumbang ka arpanet nyeta gawe dina desentralisasi jaringan teori antrian jeung packet switching
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tanggal 1 januari 1983 arpanet ngarobah inti protokol jaringanana tina ncp ka tcp/ip nandakeun awal internet sakumaha nu ayeuna urang apal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lengkah penting sejen dina ngembangna internet nyaeta ku ayana national science foundation's nsf nsfnet taun 1986

lines.value: internet diadegkeun babarengan ku kontrak komersil bi atawa multilateral.<
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example peering agreements and by technical specifications or protocols that describe how to exchange data over the network
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these protocols are formed by discussion within the internet engineering task force ietf and its working groups which are open to public participation and review
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these committees produce documents that are known as request for comments documents rfcs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some rfcs are raised to the status of internet standard by the internet architecture board iab
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the most used protocols in the internet protocol suite are ip tcp udp dns ppp slip icmp pop3 imap smtp http https ssh telnet transfer protocol ldap and ssl
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the popular services on the internet that make use of these protocols are e mail usenet newsgroups file sharing the world wide web gopher session access wais finger irc muds and mushs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: of these e mail and the world wide web are clearly the most used and many other services are built upon them such as mailing lists and web logs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the internet makes it possible to provide real time services such as web radio and webcasts that can be accessed from anywhere in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some other popular services of the internet were not created this way but were originally based on proprietary systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these include irc icq aim cddb and gnutella
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there have been many analyses of the internet and its structure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example it has been determined that the internet ip routing structure and hypertext links of the world wide web are examples of scale free networks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similar to how the commercial internet providers connect via internet exchange points research networks tend to interconnect into large subnetworks such as
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: internet oge mibanda pangaruh nu nyosok jero ka na pangaweruh jeung sawangan dunya.dibandingkeun jeung ensiklopedi sarta pabukon tradisional internet mintonkeun hiji desentralisasi informasi jeung data nu dadakan sakaligus ekstrim
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: basa nu utama dipake dina komunikasi di internet umumna inggris dumasar ka bibit buitna kailaharan basa program software jeung sabab kalemahan komputer heubeul dina narima karakter karakter lian ti alfabet kulon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cara akses internet nu umum digunakeun di imah imah nyaeta dial up jeung broadband
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: public places nu ngagunakeun internet kaasup libraries jeung internet cafes where computers with internet connections are available
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are also internet access points in public places like airport halls sometimes just for brief use while standing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various terms are used such as public internet kiosk public access terminal web payphone
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wi fi provides wireless access to the internet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hotspots providing such access include wifi cafes where one needs to bring one's own wireless enabled devices such as a notebook or pda
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these services may be free to all free to customers only or fee based
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a hotspot need not be limited to a confined location
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whole campuses and parks have been enabled even an entire downtown area
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: grassroots efforts have led to wireless community networks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: advantages of using one's own computer include more upload and download possibilities using one's favorite browser and browser settings customization may be disabled on a public computer and integrating activities on the internet and on one's own computer using one's own programs and data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: using public computers one can use one's email box as a storage area for data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for programs one may do the same but the size of the mailbox and restrictions on the public computer limit the possibilities of running one's own programs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another option is remotely hosted files that can be accessed from any internet connected machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: companies such as apple offer services that allow users to upload files as a sort of virtual drive countries with particularly good internet access include south korea where 50% of the population has broadband access sweden canada where 616% of households use the internet ) and the united states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: teori probabilitas mangrupa elmu matematik ngeunaan probabilitas atawa kamungkinan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: matematikawan mikirkeun yen probabiliti salaku angka dina interval tina 0 ka 1 keur nangtukeun kajadian nu mana bener bener kajadian atawa henteu kajadian dina bentuk acak
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probabilitas is symmetric may be seen more readily by realizing that it is the same as saying two crucial concepts in the theory of probability are those of a variabel acak and of the probability distribution of a random variable see those articles for more information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pure mathematicians usually take probability theory to be the study of probability spaces and random variables &mdash an approach introduced by andrey nikolaevich kolmogorov in the 1930s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a probability space is a triple &omega f p where with &omega denumerable we can define f := powerset(&omega which is trivially a sigma algebra and the biggest one we can create using &omega
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a discrete space we can therefore omit f and just write &omega p to define it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if on the other hand &omega is non denumerable and we use f = powerset(&omega we get into trouble defining our probability measure p because f is too huge
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so we have to use a smaller sigma algebra f eg the borel algebra of &omega
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we call this sort of probability space a continuous probability space and are led to questions in measure theory when we try to define p variabel acak is a measurable function on &omega
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the number of voters who will vote for schwarzenegger in the aforementioned sample of 100 is a random variable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if x is any random variable the notation p(x &ge 60 is shorthand for p({ &omega in &omega : x(&omega &ge 60 } so that x &ge 60 is an event
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some statisticians will assign probabilities only to events that they think of as random according to their relative frequencies of occurrence or to subsets of populations as proportions of the whole those are frequentists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others assign probabilities to propositions that are uncertain according either to subjective degrees of belief in their truth or to logically justifiable degrees of belief in their truth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such persons are bayesians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a bayesian may assign a probability to the proposition that there was life on mars a billion years ago since that is uncertain a frequentist would not assign such a probability since it is not a random event that has a long run relative frequency of occurrence
lines.name: Sundanese
