lines.value: in the early period he is seen as emulating his great predecessors haydn and mozart while concurrently exploring new directions and gradually expanding the scope and ambition of his work
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some important pieces from the early period are the first and second symphonies the first six string quartets the first two piano concertos and the first twenty piano sonatas including the famous pathetique and moonlight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the middle period began shortly after beethoven's personal crisis centering around deafness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the period is noted for large scale works expressing heroism and struggle these include many of the most famous works of classical music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: middle period works include six symphonies nos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 3 8 the last three piano concertos triple concerto and his only violin concerto five string quartets nos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 7 11 the next seven piano sonatas including the waldstein and appassionata and his only opera fidelio
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven's late period began around 1816 and lasted until beethoven's death in 1827
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the late works are greatly admired for and characterized by their intellectual depth intense and highly personal expression and experimentation with forms for example the quartet in c sharp minor has seven movements while most famously his ninth symphony adds choral forces to the orchestra in the last movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this period includes the missa solemnis the last five string quartets and the last five piano sonatas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: considering the depth and extent of beethoven's artistic explorations as well as the composer's success in making himself comprehensible to the widest possible audience the austrian born british musician and writer hans keller pronounced beethoven humanity's greatest mind altogether
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven's personal life was troubled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: around age 28 he started to become deaf which led him to contemplate suicide see the 1802 heiligenstadt testament
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was attracted to unattainable married or aristocratic women he never married
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his only uncontested love affair with a known woman began in 1805 with josephine von brunswick most scholars think it ended by 1807 because she could not marry a commoner without losing her children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1812 he wrote a long love letter to a woman only identified therein as the immortal beloved several candidates have been suggested but none has won universal support
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some scholars believe his period of low productivity from about 1812 to 1816 was caused by depression resulting from beethoven's realization that he would never marry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he didn't publish anything during this period but he released an enormous amount of material in 1816
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven quarrelled often bitterly with his relatives and others including a painful and public custody battle over his nephew karl he frequently treated other people badly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he moved often and had strange personal habits such as wearing dirty clothing even as he washed compulsively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nonetheless he had a close and devoted circle of friends his entire life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many listeners perceive an echo of beethoven's life in his music which often depicts struggle followed by triumph
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this description is often applied to beethoven's creation of masterpieces in the face of his severe personal difficulties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his last musical sketches belong to the composition of a string quintet in c major
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven was often in poor health
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to one of his letters his abdominal problems began while he was still in bonn and thus can be dated to before 1792
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1826 his health took a drastic turn for the worse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the autopsy report indicates serious problems with his liver gall bladder spleen and pancreas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is no general agreement on the exact cause of death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern research on a lock of beethoven's hair cut from his head the day after he died and a piece of his skull taken from his grave in 1863 both now at the beethoven center in san jose california show that lead poisoning could well have contributed to his ill health and ultimately to his death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the source or sources of the lead poisoning is unknown but may have been fish lead compounds used to sweeten wines or pewter drinking vessels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is unlikely that lead poisoning was the cause of his deafness which several researchers think was caused by paget's disease cochlear otosclerosis or an autoimmune disorder such as systemic lupus erythematosus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the hair analyses did not detect mercury which is consistent with the view that beethoven did not have syphilis syphilis was treated with mercury compounds at the time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the absence of drug metabolites suggests beethoven avoided opiate painkillers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven died on 26 march 1827 after a long illness in the midst of a fierce thunderstorm and legend has it that the dying man shook his fists in defiance of the heavens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was buried in the wahringer cemetery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: twenty months later the body of franz schubert was buried next to beethoven's
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1888 both schubert's and beethoven's graves were moved to the zentralfriedhof central cemetery where they can now be found next to those of johann strauss i and johannes brahms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :'main article beethoven's musical style and innovations beethoven is viewed as one of the most important transitional figures between the classical and romantic eras of musical history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as far as musical form is concerned he built on the principles of sonata form and motivic development that he had inherited from haydn and mozart but greatly extended them writing longer and more ambitious movements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but beethoven also radically redefined the symphony transforming it from the rigidly structured four ordered movements form of haydn's era to a fairly open ended form that could sustain as many movements as necessary and of whatever form as necessary to give the work cohesion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during his lifetime beethoven also radically influenced the evolution of the piano
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there had previously existed two common schools of piano making in vienna the instruments were made light and easy to play for purposes of precision with less dynamic range whereas those in london had a fuller sound with heavier keyboard action
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven though living in vienna had adopted a much heavier style of playing than most of his contemporaries and although he was not the only pianist of the time to lobby for a heavier instrument he was the only one whose musical genius had become synonymous with the artistic culture of vienna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more specifically beethoven had connections to the prominent piano manufacturer andreas streicher and as beethoven's esteem increased the pianos in vienna evolved to fit his specific taste
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also history of sonata form and romantic music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beethoven was much taken by the ideals of the enlightenment and by the growing romanticism in europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he initially dedicated his third symphony the eroica italian for heroic to napoleon in the belief that the general would sustain the democratic and republican ideals of the french revolution but in 1804 tore out the title page upon which he had written a dedication to napoleon as napoleon's imperial ambitions became clear renamed the symphony as the sinfonia eroica composta per festeggiare il sovvenire di un grand uomo or in english composed to celebrate the memory of a great man
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the fourth movement of his ninth symphony features an elaborate choral setting of schiller's ode an die freude ode to joy an optimistic hymn championing the brotherhood of humanity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scholars disagree on beethoven's religious beliefs and the role they played in his work
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for discussion see ludwig van beethoven's religious beliefs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a continuing controversy surrounding beethoven is whether he was a romantic or a classical composer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as documented elsewhere since the meanings of the word romantic and the definition of the period romanticism both vary by discipline beethoven's inclusion as a member of that movement or period must be looked at in context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if we consider the romantic movement as an aesthetic epoch in literature and the arts generally beethoven sits squarely in the first half along with literary romantics such as the german poets goethe and schiller whose texts both he and franz schubert drew on for songs and the english poet percy shelley
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was also called a romantic by contemporaries such as spohr and eta hoffman
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he is often considered the composer of the first song cycle and was influenced by romantic folk idioms for example in his use of the work of robert burns
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he set dozens of such poems and arranged folk melodies for voice piano violin and cello
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if on the other hand we consider the context of musicology where romantic music is dated later the matter is one of considerably greater debate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for some experts beethoven is not a romantic and his being one is a myth for others he stands as a transitional figure or an immediate precursor to romanticism the inventor of the romantic period for others he is the prototypical or even archetypal romantic composer complete with myth of heroic genius and individuality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the marker buoy of romanticism has been pushed back and forth several times by scholarship and it remains a subject of intense debate in no small part because beethoven is seen as a seminal figure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to those for whom the enlightenment represents the basis of modernity he must therefore be unequivocally a classicist while for those who see the romantic sensibility as a key to later aesthetics including the aesthetics of our own time he must be a romantic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: between these two extremes there are of course innumerable gradations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: listening to beethoven's music yields another possible scholarly analysis there is definitely an evolution in style from beethoven's earliest compositions to his later works
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the young beethoven can be seen toiling to conform to the aesthetic models of his contemporaries he wants to write music that is acceptable in the society of his days
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later there is much more iconoclasm in his approach like adding a chorus to a symphony where a symphony had until then only been a purely instrumental genre
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that the question changes from whether beethoven was a classicist or a romantic to where is the pivotal moment that beethoven tilted from dominant classicism to dominant romanticism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most scholars seem to concur the presentation of the 5th and 6th symphonies in a single concert in 1808 is probably closest to that pivotal point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 5th symphony he let a short pounding motto theme run through all movements of the composition unheard of until then
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then the 6th symphony was the first example of a symphony composed as program music what in romanticism became standard practice and it broke up the traditional arrangement of a symphony in four movements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: yet after that beethoven still wrote his gentle 8th symphony and some innocent sounding chamber music for the english market
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however by the end of the first decade of the 19th century beethoven the romantic was without a doubt primary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast carl dahlhaus argues that the evolution of beethoven's style actually takes him past romanticism to a place where he was separate from the music of his contemporaries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dahlhaus points out that our understanding of beethoven as a romantic composer derives largely from beethoven's early middle period which contains the symphony no
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 3 and symphony no
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 5 beethoven's impact on other romantic composers however is taken largely from works between opp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 74 and 97 of the second half of the so called middle period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dahlhaus argues that the tradition of romantic music is essentially a tradition of schubertian music and that beethoven's influence on schubert is largely taken from opp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the time beethoven reaches the late period he is such an individual as to be best understood as no longer belonging to the same genre as his romantic contemporaries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern greek is still largely a synthetic language

lines.value: it is one of the few indo european languages that has retained a synthetic passive

lines.value: noticeable changes in grammar compared to classical greek include the loss of the dative the optative mood the infinitive the dual number and the participles except the past participle the adoption of the gerund the reduction in the number of noun declensions and the number of distinct forms in each declension the adoption of the modal particle ' a contraction of ' > ' > ' > ) to denote future and conditional tenses the introduction of auxiliary verb forms for certain tenses the extension to the future tense of the aspectual distinction between present imperfect and aorist the loss of the third person imperative and the simplification of the system of grammatical prefixes such as augmentation and reduplication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of these features are shared with other languages spoken in the balkan peninsula see balkan linguistic union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its oldest discovered inscriptions date to the 8th or 9th century bc it assumed its final form in athens in 403 bc and displaced other regional variants due to its use for the attic koine dialect during the hellenistic era

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hedges and olkin 1985 noted that one could adjust effect size estimates by taking into account the sample size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the problem with cohen's d is that the outcome is heavily influenced by the denominator in the equation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if one standard deviation is larger than the other then the denominator is weighted in that direction and the effect size is more conservative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however surely it makes more sense to put stock in the larger sample size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hedges g incorporates sample size by both computing a denominator which looks at the sample sizes of the respective standard deviations and also makes an adjustment to the overall effect size based on this sample size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the formula for hedges g as used by software such as the effect size generator is effect size measure for hierarchical multiple regression is defined as : effect sizes of 0.02 0.15 and 0.35 are considered small medium and large respectively cohen 1988
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the odds ratio is another useful effect size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is appropriate when both variables are binary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example consider a study on spelling
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a control group two students pass the class for every one who fails so the odds of passing are two to one or more briefly 2/1 = 2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the treatment group six students pass for every one who fails so the odds of passing are six to one or 6/1 = 6
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the effect size can be computed by noting that the odds of passing in the treatment group are three times higher than in the control group because 6 divided by 2 is 3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore the odds ratio is 3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however odds ratio statistics are on a different scale to cohen's d so this 3 is not comparable to a cohen's d of 3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: loss functions sacara tipikal digambarkeun dina watesan keuangan dumasar kana ukuran biaya nu mungkin contona kalahiran jeung kematian dina widang public health
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: loss functions are complementary to utility functions which represent benefit and satisfaction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically for utility u loss is equal to k u where k is some arbitrary constant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: loss function satisfies the definition of a random variable so we can establish a cumulative distribution function and an nilai ekspektasi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however more commonly the loss function is expressed as a function of some other random variable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the time that a light bulb operates before failure is a random variable and we can specify the loss arising from having to cope in the dark and or replace the bulb as a function of failure time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a continuous random variable x with probability density function f(x and loss function λ(x the expected loss is minimum expected loss is widely used as a criterion for choosing between prospects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is closely related to the criterion of maximum expected utility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the consequences of bayesian inference is that in addition to experimental data the loss function does not in itself wholly determine a decision
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what is important is the relationship between the loss function and the prior probability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so it is possible to have two different loss functions which lead to the same decision when the prior probability distributions associated with each compensate for the details of each loss function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: combining the three elements of the prior probability the data and the loss function then allows decisions to be based on maximising the subjective expected utility a concept introduced by leonard j savage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also argued that using non bayesian methods such as minimax the loss function should be based on the idea of regret i.e the loss associated with a decision should be the difference between the consequences of the best decision that could have been taken had the underlying circumstances been known and the decision that was in fact taken before they were known
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a series of measurements of a process may be treated as a deret waktu and then trend estimation is the application of statistical techniques to make and justify statements about trends in the data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: assuming the underlying process is a physical system that is incompletely understood one may thereby construct a model independent of anything known about the physics of the process to explain the behaviour of the measurement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in particular one may wish to know if the measurements exhibit an increasing or decreasing trend that can be statistically distinguished from random behaviour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example take daily average temperatures at a given location from winter to summer or the global temperature series over the last 100 years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: particularly in that latter case issues of homogeneity is the series equally reliable throughout its length are important
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the moment we shall simplify the discussion and neglect those points
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this page does not attempt a full mathematical treatment merely an exposition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: given a set of data and the desire to produce some kind of model of that data model in this case meaning a function fitted through the data there are a variety of functions that can be chosen for the fit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but if there is no prior understanding of the data the simplest function to fit is a straight line and thus this is the default
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: continuing once it has been decided to fit a straight line there are various ways to do so but the overwhelming default is the least-squares fit equivalent to minimisation of the l 2 norm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see least squares
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus given a set of data points is minimised
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can always be done in closed form
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the rest of this article trend will mean the least squares trend
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it's what it means in 99% of cases everywhere else
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: now we have a trend
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but is it significant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and what do we mean by significant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: samemeh urang nempo kana tren data riil kudu ngarti heula tren dina data random
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if we take a series which is known to be random fair dice falls or computer generated random numbers and fit a trend line through the data the chances of a truly zero trend are negligible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but we would probably expect the trend to be small
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if we take a series with a given degree of noise and a given length say 100 points and generate a large number of such series say 100000 series we can then calculate the trends from these 100000 series and empirically establish a distribution of trends that are to be expected from such random data see diagram
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such a distribution will be normal central limit theorem except in pathological cases since in a slightly non obvious way of thinking about it the trend is a linear combination of the
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: complication we may be interested in positive and negative trends 2-tailed or may have prior knowledge that only positive or only negative trends are of interest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the above discussion the distribution of trends was calculated empirically from a large number of trials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in simple cases normally distributed random noise being a classic the distribution of trends can be calculated exactly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose we then take another series with approximately the same variance properties as our random series
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we do not know in advance whether it really has a trend in it so we calculate the trend are usually unknown constants and the s as residuals and calculating the variance of the s.one particular special case of great interest the global temperature time series is known not to be homogeneous in time apart from anything else the number of weather observations has generally increased with time and thus the error associated with estimating the global temperature from a limited set of observations has decreased with time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fitting a trend to this data this can be taken into account as described above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once we know the noise of the series we can then assess the significance of the trend by making the null hypothesis that the trend the trend will be obvious if the trend will be buried in the noise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if we consider a concrete example the global surface temperature record of the past 140 years as presented by the ipcc then the interannual variation is about 0.2 °c and the trend about 0.6 °c over 140 years with 95% confidence limits of 0.2 °c by coincidence about the same value as the interannual variation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hence the trend is statistically different from 0
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this alone however tells us nothing about the physical causes of the temperature change
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the least-squares fitting process throws out a value r squared which is the square of the residuals of the data after the fit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it says what fraction of the variance of the data is explained by the fitted trend line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: is does not relate to the significance of the trend line see graph
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a noisy series can have a very low r2 value but a very high significance of fit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often filtering a series increases r2 whilst making little difference to the fitted trend or significance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the above discussion assumed the data could be represented as trend + noise with the noise at each data point being independent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is important as it makes an enormous difference to the ease with which the statistics can be analysed

lines.value: simulation is often used in the training of civilian and military personnel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this usually occurs when it is prohibitively expensive or simply too dangerous to allow trainees to use the real equipment in the real world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in such situations they will spend time learning valuable lessons in a safe virtual environment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often the convenience is to permit mistakes during training for a safety critical system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: training simulations typically come in one of three categories
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: main article flight simulator a flight simulator is used to train pilots on the ground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it permits a pilot to crash his simulated aircraft without being hurt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: flight simulators are often used to train pilots to operate aircraft in extremely hazardous situations such as landings with no engines or complete electrical or hydraulic failures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the simulator is normally cheaper to operate than a real trainer aircraft
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: simulation is an important feature when engineering systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example in electrical engineering delay lines may be used to simulate propagation delay and phase shift caused by an actual transmission line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly dummy loads may be used to simulate impedance without simulating propagation and is used in situations where propagation is unwanted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a simulator may imitate only a few of the operations and functions of the unit it simulates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contrast with emulate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: source federal standard 1037c
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: main article computer simulation related article model computer simulation has become a useful part of modeling many natural systems in physics chemistry and biology and human systems in economics and social science the computational sociology as well as in engineering to gain insight into the operation of those systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in such simulations the model behaviour will change according to a set of initial parameters such as a meteorological model
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computer simulations are often considered human out of the loop simulations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditionally the formal modeling of systems has been via a mathematical model which attempts to find analytical solutions to problems which enables the prediction of the behaviour of the system from a set of parameters and initial conditions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computer simulation is often used an adjunct to or substitution for modeling systems for which simple closed form analytic solutions are not possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are many different types of computer simulation the common feature they all share is the attempt to generate a sample of representative scenarios for a model in which a complete enumeration of all possible states of the model would be prohibitive or impossible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is increasingly common to hear simulations of many kinds referred to as synthetic environments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this label has been adopted to broaden the definition of simulation to encompass virtually any computer based representation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in computer science simulation has an even more a specialized meaning alan turing uses the term simulation to refer to what happens when a digital computer runs a state transition table runs a program that describes the state transitions inputs and outputs of a subject discrete state machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the computer simulates the subject machine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in computer programming a simulator is often used to execute a program that has to run on some inconvenient type of computer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example simulators are usually used to debug a microprogram
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the operation of the computer is simulated all of the information about the computer's operation is directly available to the programmer and the speed and execution of the simulation can be varied at will
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: simulators may also be used to interpret fault trees or test vlsi logic designs before they are constructed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many video games are also simulators implemented inexpensively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are sometimes called sim games
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in theoretical computer science the term simulation represents a relation between state transition systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is useful in the study of operational semantics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrowroot tubers contain about 23% starch
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are first washed then cleaned of the paper like scale washed again drained and finally reduced to a pulp by beating them in mortars or subjecting them to the action of the wheel rasp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the milky liquid thus obtained is passed through a coarse cloth or hair sieve and the pure starch which is insoluble is allowed to settle at the bottom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the wet starch is dried in the sun or in a drying house
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the result is a powder the arrowroot of commerce and it is at once packed for market in air tight cans packages or cases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrowroot starch has in the past been quite extensively adulterated with potato starch and other similar substances so care is needed in selection and buying
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pure arrowroot like other pure starches is a light white powder the mass feeling firm to the finger and crackling like newly fallen snow when rubbed or pressed odorless when dry but emitting a faint peculiar odor when mixed with boiling water and swelling on cooking into perfect jelly which can be used to make a food for vegetarians very smooth in consistency—unlike adulterated articles mixed with potato flour and other starches of lower value which contain larger particles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrowroot is used as an article of diet in the form of biscuits puddings jellies cakes hot sauces etc and also with beef tea milk or veal broth noodles in korean cuisine or boiled with a little flavoring added as an easily digestible food for children and people with dietary restrictions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrowroot makes clear shimmering fruit gels and prevents ice crystals from forming in homemade ice cream
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can also be used as a thickener for acidic foods such as oriental sweet and sour sauce
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the lack of gluten in arrowroot flour makes it useful as a replacement for wheat flour in baking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like other pure starches however arrowroot is almost pure carbohydrate and devoid of protein thus it does not equal wheat flour nutritionally
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrowroot thickens at a lower temperature than does flour or cornstarch
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is recommended to mix arrowroot with a cool liquid before adding to a hot fluid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mixture should be heated only until the mixture thickens and removed immediately to prevent the mixture from thinning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: overheating tends to break down arrowroot's thickening property
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: substitute two teaspoons of arrowroot for one tablespoon of cornstarch or one teaspoon of arrowroot for one tablespoon of wheat flour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tapioca does not have the same gelling and nutritional properties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if you eat a large quantity of arrowroot it may cause stomach pains and very bad gut illnesses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archaeological studies in the americas show evidence of arrowroot cultivation as early as 7000 years ago
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the name may come from aru aru meal of meals in the language of the caribbean arawak people for whom the plant is a staple
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has also been suggested that the name comes from arrowroot's use in treating poison arrow wounds as it draws out the poison when applied to the site of the injury
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the early days of carbonless copy papers arrowroot because of its fine grain size was a widely used ingredient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after an economical way of centrifugally separating wheat flour was devised arrowroot lost its role in papermaking see arrowroot paper

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: johann sebastian bach 21 maret 1685 28 juli 1750 nyaeta saurang komponis jeung organis jerman mangsa baroque nu geus diaku salaku salah sahiji lulugu komposer sapanjang jaman
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: karyana nu jero ajen kaelmuanana kamampuhan tehnisna sarta kaendahan artistikna geus jadi inspirasi pikeun ampir sakabeh musisi dina tradisi eropah ti mozart nepi ka schoenberg
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: j s bach was born in eisenach germany in 1685 and died in 1750 at the age of 65
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his father johann ambrosius bach was the town piper in eisenach a post that entailed organizing all the secular music in town as well as participating in church music at the direction of the church organist and his uncles were also all professional musicians ranging from church organists and court chamber musicians to composers although bach would later surpass them all in his art
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in an era when sons were expected to assist in their fathers work we can assume j s bach began copying music and playing various instruments at an early age
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bach's mother died when he was still a young boy and his father suddenly passed away when j s bach was 9 at which time j s bach moved in with his older brother johann christoph bach who was the organist of ohrdruf in germany
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while in his brother's house j s bach continued copying studying and playing music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to one popular legend of the young composer's curiosity late one night when the house was asleep he retrieved a manuscript which may have been a collection of works by johann christoph's former mentor johann pachelbel from his brother's music cabinet and began to copy it by the moonlight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this went on nightly until johann christoph heard the young sebastian playing some of the distinctive tunes from his private library at which point the elder brother demanded to know how sebastian had come to learn them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was at ohrdruf that bach began to learn about organ building
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ohrdruf church's instrument it seems was in constant need of minor repairs and young j s bach was often sent into the belly of the old organ to tighten adjust or replace various parts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: realizing that in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries the church organ with its moving bellows manifold stops and complicated mechanical linkages from the keys and pedals to the many actual pipes was the most complex machine in any european town we can imagine that sebastian may have been awed by it much as modern boys are fascinated by cars trucks and planes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this hands on experience with the innards of the instrument would provide a unique counterpoint to his unequalled skill at playing the instrument j s bach was equally at home talking with organ builders and performers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while in school and as a young man bach's curiosity compelled him to seek out great organists of germany such as georg bohm dietrich buxtehude and johann adam reinken often taking journeys of considerable length to hear them play
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was also influenced by the work of nicholas bruhns
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shortly after graduation bach completed latin school when he was 18 an impressive accomplishment in his day especially considering that he was the first in his family to finish school bach took a post as organist at arnstadt in germany in 1703
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he apparently felt cramped in the small town and began to seek his fortune elsewhere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: owing to his virtuosity he was soon offered a more lucrative organist post in muhlhausen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of bach's earliest extant compositions date to this period including according to some scholars his famous toccata and fugue in d minor but owing to the general immaturity of this early bach music much of the music bach wrote during this time has unfortunately been lost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: still not content as organist of muhlhausen in 1708 bach took a position as court organist and concert master at the ducal court in weimar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here he had opportunity to not only play the organ but also compose for it and play a more varied repertoire of concert music with the dukes ensemble
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a devotee of contrapuntal music bach's steady output of fugues begins in weimar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the best known example of his fugal writing is probably the well tempered clavier which comprises 48 preludes and fugues two for each major and minor key a monumental work not only for its masterful use of counterpoint but also for exploring for the first time the full glory of keys--and the means of expression made possible by their slight differences from each other--available to keyboard musicians when their instruments are tuned according to andreas werckmeister's system of well temperament or similar system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also during his tenure at weimar bach began work on the orgelbuchlein for wilhelm friedemann
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this little book of organ music contains traditional lutheran church hymns harmonized by bach and compiled in a way to be instructive to organ students
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this incomplete work introduces two major themes into bach's corpus firstly his dedication to teaching and secondly his love of the traditional chorale as a form and source of inspiration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bach's dedication to teaching is especially remarkable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there was hardly any period in his life when he did not have a full time apprentice studying with him and there were always numerous private students studying in bach's house including such 18th century notables as johann friedrich agricola
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: still today students of nearly every instrument encounter bach's works early and revisit him throughout their careers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sensing increasing political tensions in the ducal court of weimar bach began once again to search out a more stable job conducive to his musical interests
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prince leopold of anhalt cothen hired bach to serve as his kapellmeister that is director of music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prince leopold himself a musician appreciated bach's talents compensated him well and gave him considerable latitude in composing and performing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the prince was calvinist and did not use elaborate music in his worship so that most of bach's work from this period is secular in nature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the brandenburg concerti as well as many other instrumental works including the suites for solo cello the sonatas and partitas for solo violin and the orchestral suites date to this period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1723 j s bach was appointed cantor and musical director of st thomas church in leipzig in germany
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this post required him to not only instruct the students of the st thomas school in singing but also to provide weekly music at the two main churches in leipzig
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rising above and beyond the call of duty bach endeavored to compose a new church piece or cantata every week
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this challenging schedule which basically amounted to writing an hour's worth of music every week in addition to his more menial duties at the school produced some genuinely sublime music most of which has been preserved
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most of the cantatas from this period expound upon the sunday readings from the bible for the week in which they were originally performed some were written using traditional church hymns such as wachet auf
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ruft uns die stimme and nun komm der heiden heiland as inspiration for the music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on holy days such as christmas good friday and easter bach produced cantatas of particular brilliance most notably the magnificat for christmas and st matthew passion for good friday
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the composer himself considered the monumental st matthew passion among his greatest masterpieces in his correspondence he referred to it as his great passion and carefully prepared a calligraphic manuscript of the work which required every available musician in town for its performance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bach's representation of the essence and message of christianity in his religious music is considered by many to be so powerful and beautiful that in germany he is sometimes referred to as the fifth evangelist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bach married his second cousin maria barbara bach on october 17 1707 after receiving a small inheritance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they had 7 children 4 of whom survived to adulthood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: little is known of maria barbara
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: she died suddenly on july 7 1720 while bach was travelling with prince leopold
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while at cothen bach met anna magdalena wilcke a young soprano
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they married on december 11 1721
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the age difference she was 17 years his junior the couple seem to have had a very happy marriage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anna supported johann's composing many final scores are in her hand while he encouraged her singing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: together they had 13 children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all the bach children were musically inclined which must have given the aging composer much pride
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his sons wilhelm friedemann bach johann gottfried bernhard bach johann christoph friedrich bach johann christian bach and carl philipp emanuel bach all became accomplished musicians with c p e bach winning the respect of wolfgang amadeus mozart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the barriers to women having professional careers were great all of bach's daughters most likely sang and possibly played in their father's ensembles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the only one of the bach daughters to marry elisabeth juliana friederica choose as husband bach's student johann christoph altnickol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most of the music we have from bach was passed on through his children who preserved much of what c p e bach called the old bach archive after his father's death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at leipzig bach seems to have fit in amongst the professoriate of the university with many professors standing as god parents for his children and some of the university's men of letters and theology providing many of the librettos for his cantatas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this last capacity bach enjoyed a particularly fruitful relationship with the poet picander
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sebastian and anna magdalena also welcomed friends family and fellow musicians from all over germany into their home court musicians at dresden and berlin as well as musicians including george philipp telemann one of carl philipp emanuel's godfathers made frequent visits to bach's house and may have kept up frequent correspondence with him
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly george friedrich handel who was born in the same year as bach made several trips to germany but bach was unable to meet him a fact he regretted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having spent much of the 1720s composing weekly cantatas bach assembled a sizable repertoire of church music that with minor revisions and a few additions allowed him to continue performing impressive sunday music programs while pursuing other interests in secular music both vocal and instrumental
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of these later works were collaborations with leipzig's collegium musicum but some were increasingly introspective and abstract compositional masterpieces that represent the pinnacle of bach's art
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these erudite works start with the four volumes of his clavier-ubung keyboard practice a set of keyboard works to inspire and challenge organists and lovers of music that includes the 6 partitas for keyboard vol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: i the italian concerto the french overture vol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ii and the goldberg variations vol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: iv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the same time bach wrote a complete mass in b minor which incorporated newly composed movements with portions from earlier works
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the mass was never performed during the composer's lifetime it is considered to be among the greatest of his choral works
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after meeting king frederick ii of prussia in potsdam in 1747 who played a theme for bach and challenged the famous musician to improvise a six part fugue based on his theme bach presented the king with a musical offering including several fugues and canons based on the royal theme later using a theme of his own design bach produced the art of fugue
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these 14 fugues called contrapuncti by bach are all based on the same theme demonstrating the versatility of a simple melody
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during his life time he composed over 1000 pieces
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: johann sebastian bach's contributions to music or to borrow a term popularized by his student lorenz christoph mizler musical science are frequently compared to the original geniuses of william shakespeare in english literature and isaac newton in physics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: johann sebastian bach died in 1750

lines.value: an electronic component is any indivisible electronic building block packaged in a discrete form with two or more connecting leads or metallic pads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: components are intended to be connected together usually by soldering to a printed circuit board to create an electronic circuit with a particular function for example an amplifier radio receiver or oscillator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: components may be packaged singly resistor capacitor transistor diode etc or in more or less complex groups as integrated circuits operational amplifier resistor array logic gate etc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: active components are sometimes called devices rather than components
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most analog electronic appliances such as radio receivers are constructed from combinations of a few types of basic circuits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analog circuits use a continuous range of voltage as opposed to discrete levels as in digital circuits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the number of different analog circuits so far devised is huge especially because a circuit can be defined as anything from a single component to systems containing thousands of components
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analog circuits are sometimes called linear circuits although many non linear effects are used in analog circuits such as mixers modulators etc good examples of analog circuits are vacuum tube and transistor amplifiers operational amplifiers and oscillators
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some analog circuitry these days may use digital or even microprocessor techniques to improve upon the basic performance of the circuit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this type of circuit is usually called mixed signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes it may be difficult to differentiate between analog and digital circuits as they have elements of both linear and non linear operation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example is the comparator which takes in a continuous range of voltage but puts out only one of two levels as in a digital circuit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly an overdriven transistor amplifier can take on the characteristics of a controlled switch having essentially two levels of output
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: digital circuits are electric circuits based on a number of discrete voltage levels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: digital circuits are the most common physical representation of boolean algebra and are the basis of all digital computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to most engineers the terms digital circuit digital system and logic are interchangeable in the context of digital circuits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most cases the number of different states of a node is two represented by two voltage levels labeled low and high
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often low will be near zero volts and high will be at a higher level depending on the supply voltage in use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers electronic clocks and programmable logic controllers used to control industrial processes are constructed of digital circuits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: digital signal processors are another example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: building blocks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mixed signal circuits refers to integrated circuits ics which have both analog circuits and digital circuits combined on a single semiconductor die or on the same circuit board
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mixed signal circuits are becoming increasingly common
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mixed circuits contain both analog and digital components
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analog to digital converters and digital to analog converters are the primary examples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other examples are transmission gates and buffers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: heat generated by electronic circuitry must be dissipated to prevent immediate failure and improve long term reliability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: techniques for heat dissipation can include heatsinks and fans for air cooling and other forms of computer cooling such as liquid cooling for computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these techniques use convection conduction & radiation of heat energy

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: heitler and london's method was extended by the american chemists john c slater and linus pauling to become the valence bond vb [or heitler london slater pauling hlsp)] method
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this method attention is primarily devoted to the pairwise interactions of atoms and this method therefore correlates closely with classical chemists drawing of bonds between atoms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an alternative approach was developed by friedrich hund and robert s mulliken in which the electrons are described by mathematical functions delocalized over an entire molecule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the hund mulliken approach [or molecular orbital mo method] is less intuitive to chemists but since it turns out to be more capable of predicting properties than the vb method it is virtually the only method used in recent years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: caution this method only works with centered data i.e data which have been shifted by the sample mean so as to have an average of zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some practitioners prefer an uncentered non-pearson-compliant correlation coefficient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see the example below for a comparison
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as an example suppose five countries are found to have gross national products of 1 2 3 5 and 8 billion dollars respectively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose these same five countries in the same order are found to have 11% 12% 13% 15% and 18% poverty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then let x and y be ordered 5-element vectors containing the above data x = 1 2 3 5 8 and y = 0.11 0.12 0.13 0.15 0.18
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the usual procedure for finding the angle between two vectors see dot product the uncentered correlation coefficient is note that the above data were deliberately chosen to be perfectly correlated y = 0.10 + 0.01 x the pearson correlation coefficient must therefore be exactly one
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: centering the data shifting x by e(x = 3.8 and y by e(y = 0.138 yields x = -2.8 -1.8 -0.8 1.2 4.2 and y = -0.028 -0.018 -0.008 0.012 0.042 from which as expected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several authors have offered guidelines for the interpretation of a correlation coefficient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cohen 1988 for example has suggested the following interpretations for correlations in psychological research in the table on the right
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as cohen himself has observed however all such criteria are in some ways arbitrary and should not be observed too strictly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is because the interpretation of a correlation coefficient depends on the context and purposes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a correlation of 0.9 may be very low if one is verifying a physical law using high quality instruments but may be regarded as very high in the social sciences where there may be a greater contribution from complicating factors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's correlation coefficient is a parametric statistic and when distributions are not normal it may be less useful than non parametric correlation methods such as chi square point biserial correlation spearman's &rho and kendall's &tau
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are a little less powerful than parametric methods if the assumptions underlying the latter are met but are less likely to give distorted results when the assumptions fail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to get a measure for more general dependencies in the data also nonlinear it is better to use the correlation ratio which is able to detect almost any functional dependency or mutual information total correlation which is capable of detecting even more general dependencies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the polychoric correlation is another correlation applied to ordinal data that aims to estimate the correlation between theorised latent variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the information given by a correlation coefficient is not enough to define the dependence structure between random variables to fully capture it we must consider a copula between them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the correlation coefficient completely defines the dependence structure only in very particular cases for example when the cumulative distribution functions are the multivariate normal distributions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the case of elliptic distributions it characterizes the hyper-)ellipses of equal density however it does not completely characterize the dependence structure for example the a multivariate t distribution's degrees of freedom determine the level of tail dependence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the correlation matrix of n random variables x 1 , x n is the n &times n matrix whose i,j entry is corr(x i , x j ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the measures of correlation used are product moment coefficients the correlation matrix is the same as the covariance matrix of the standardized random variables x i sd(x i ) for i = 1 , n consequently it is necessarily a positive semidefinite matrix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the correlation matrix is symmetric because the correlation between be an r by c matrix with every element 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then d is the data transformed so every random variable has zero mean and t is the data transformed so all variables have zero mean unit variance and zero correlation with all other variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the conventional dictum that correlation does not imply causation means that correlation cannot be validly used to infer a causal relationship between the variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this dictum should not be taken to mean that correlations cannot indicate causal relations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the causes underlying the correlation if any may be indirect and unknown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: consequently establishing a correlation between two variables is not a sufficient condition to establish a causal relationship in either direction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here is a simple example hot weather may cause both crime and ice cream purchases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore crime is correlated with ice cream purchases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but crime does not cause ice cream purchases and ice cream purchases do not cause crime
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a correlation between age and height in children is fairly causally transparent but a correlation between mood and health in people is less so
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: does improved mood lead to improved health
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: or does good health lead to good mood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: or does some other factor underlie both
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: or is it pure coincidence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words a correlation can be taken as evidence for a possible causal relationship but cannot indicate what the causal relationship if any might be
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while pearson correlation indicates the strength of a linear relationship between two variables its value alone may not be sufficient to evaluate this relationship especially in the case where the assumption of normality is incorrect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the image on the right shows scatterplots of anscombe's quartet a set of four different pairs of variables created by francis anscombe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the four ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however as can be seen on the plots the distribution of the variables is very different
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first one top left seems to be distributed normally and corresponds to what one would expect when considering two variables correlated and following the assumption of normality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the second one top right is not distributed normally while an obvious relationship between the two variables can be observed it is not linear and the pearson correlation coefficient is not relevant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the third case bottom left the linear relationship is perfect except for one outlier which exerts enough influence to lower the correlation coefficient from 1 to 0.81
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finally the fourth example bottom right shows another example when one outlier is enough to produce a high correlation coefficient even though the relationship between the two variables is not linear
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these examples indicate that the correlation coefficient as a summary statistic cannot replace the individual examination of the data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following algorithm in pseudocode will estimate correlation with good numerical stability sum_sq_x = 0 sum_sq_y = 0 sum_coproduct = 0 mean_x = x[1] mean_y = y[1] for i in 2 to n sweep = i 1.0 i delta_x = x[i] mean_x delta_y = y[i] mean_y sum_sq_x += delta_x * delta_x * sweep sum_sq_y += delta_y * delta_y * sweep sum_coproduct += delta_x * delta_y * sweep mean_x += delta_x i mean_y += delta_y i pop_sd_x = sqrt( sum_sq_x n ) pop_sd_y = sqrt( sum_sq_y n ) cov_x_y = sum_coproduct n correlation = cov_x_y pop_sd_x * pop_sd_y for an enlightening experiment check the correlation of {900000000 + i for i=1...100} with {900000000 i for i=1...100} perhaps with a few values modified
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: poor algorithms will fail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the liver is one of the only internal human organs capable of natural regeneration of lost tissue as little as 25% of remaining liver can regenerate into a whole liver again
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is predominantly due to the hepatocytes acting as unipotential stem cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is also some evidence of bipotential stem cells called oval cells which can differentiate into either hepatocytes or cholangiocytes cells that line the bile ducts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: apart from a patch where it connects to the diaphragm the liver is covered entirely by visceral peritoneum a thin double layered membrane that reduces friction against other organs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the peritoneum folds back on itself to form the falciform ligament and the right and left triangular ligaments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these ligaments are in no way related to the true anatomic ligaments in joints and have essentially no functional importance but they are easily recognizable surface landmarks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional gross anatomy divided the liver into four lobes based on surface features
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the falciform ligament is visible on the front anterior side of the liver
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this divides the liver into a left anatomical lobe and a right anatomical lobe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the liver is flipped over to look at it from behind the visceral surface there are two additional lobes between the right and left
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are the caudate lobe the more superior and below this the quadrate lobe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from behind the lobes are divided up by the ligamentum venosum and ligamentum teres anything left of these is the left lobe the transverse fissure or porta hepatis divides the caudate from the quadrate lobe and the right sagittal fossa which the inferior vena cava runs over separates these two lobes from the right lobe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the functional lobes are separated by a plane joining the gallbladder fossa to the inferior vena cava

lines.value: basalt which erupts under open air that is subaerially forms three distinct types of lava or volcanic deposits scoria ash or cinder breccia and lava flows

lines.value: basalt in the tops of subaerial lava flows and cinder cones will often be highly vesiculated imparting a lightweight frothy texture to the rock

lines.value: basaltic cinders are often red coloured by oxidised iron from weathered iron rich minerals such as pyroxene
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a'a types of blocky cinder and breccia flows of thick viscous basaltic magma are common in hawaii and other basalts which erupt slightly cooler
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pahoehoe is a highly fluid hot form of basalt which tends to form thin aprons of molten lava which fill up hollows and form lava lakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lava tubes are common features of pahoehoe eruptions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: basaltic tuff or pyroclastic rocks are rare but not unknown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usually basalt is too hot and fluid to build up sufficient pressure to form explosive lava eruptions but occasionally this will happen by trapping of the lava within the volcanic throat and build up of volcanic gases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hawaii's mauna loa erupted in this way in the 19th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another example is the 0.2ma diamond head tuff hawaii
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: maar volcanoes are typical of small basalt tuffs formed by explosive eruption of basalt through the crust forming an apron of mixed basalt and wall rock breccia and a fan of basalt tuff further out from the volcano
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: amygdaloidal structure is common in relic vesicles and beautifully crystallized species of zeolites quartz or calcite are frequently found
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: columnar basalt is formed by cooling of a thick lava flow which forms contractional joints or fractures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if a flow cools relatively rapidly significant contraction forces build up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while a flow can accommodate shrinking in the vertical direction the flow becomes less thick it cannot easily accommodate shrinking in the horizontal direction unless cracks form
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the extensive fracture network that develops results in the formation of columns
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because hexagons fit together efficiently with no vacant space a tessellation this is the most common pattern that develops
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pentagonal heptagonal or octagonal joint patterns are also known but are less common
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that the size of the columns depends loosely on the rate of cooling very rapid cooling may result in very small <1 cm diameter columns and vice versa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pillow basalts when basalt erupts underwater or flows into the sea the cold water quenches the surface and the lava forms a distinctive pillow shape through which the hot lava breaks to form another pillow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this pillow texture is very common in underwater basaltic flows and is diagnostic of an underwater eruption environment when found in ancient rocks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pillows typically consist of a fine grained core with a glassy crust and have radial jointing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: size of individual pillows vary from 10 cm up to several metres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when pahoehoe lava enters the sea it usually forms pillow basalts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however when a'a enters the ocean it forms a littoral cone a small cone shaped accumulation of tuffaceous debris formed when the blocky a'a lava enters the water and explodes from built up steam
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the island of surtsey in the atlantic is a basalt volcano which breached the ocean surface in 1963
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the initial phase of surtsey's eruption was highly explosive as the magma was quite wet causing the rock to be blown apart by the boiling steam to form a tuff and cinder cone
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has subsequently moved to a typical pahoehoe type behaviour

lines.value: glass or obsidian may be present particularly as rinds on rapidly chilled surfaces of lava flows and is commonly but not exclusively associated with underwater eruptions

lines.value: analisa power sejenna bisa samemeh priori atawa sanggeus post hoc data dikumpulkeun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a priori power analysis is conducted prior to the conducting of research and is typically used to determine an appropriate sample size to achieve adequate power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: post hoc power analysis is conducted after a study has been conducted and uses the obtained sample size and effect size to determine what the power was in the study assuming the effect size in the sample size is equal to the population effect size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: statistical tests attempt to use data from samples to determine if differences or similarities exist in a population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example to test the null hypothesis that the mean scores of men and women on a test do not differ samples of men and women are drawn the test is administered to them and the mean score of one group is compared to that of the other group using a statistical test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the power of the test is the probability that the test will find a statistically significant difference between men and women as a function of the size of the true difference between those two populations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the use of random samples which will tend to mirror the population due to mathematical properties such as the central limit theorem there is always a chance that the samples will appear to support or refute a tested hypothesis when the reality is the opposite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this risk is quantified as the power of the test and as the statistical significance level used for the test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: statistical power depends on calculating the power requires first specifying the effect size you want to detect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greater the effect size the greater the power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sensitivity can be increased by using statistical controls by increasing the reliability of measures as in psychometric reliability and by increasing the size of the sample
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: increasing sample size is the most commonly used method for increasing statistical power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although there are no formal standards for power most researchers who assess the power of their tests use 0.80 as a standard for adequacy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a common misconception by those new to statistical power is that power is a property of a study or experiment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in reality any statistical result that has a p value has an associated power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example in the context of a single multiple regression there will be a different level of statistical power associated with the overall r square and for each of the regression coefficients
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when determining an appropriate sample size for a planned study it is important to consider that power will vary across the different hypotheses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are times when the recommendations of power analysis regarding sample size will be inadequate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: power analysis is appropriate when the concern is with the correct acceptance or rejection of a null hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many contexts the issue is less about determining if there is or is not a difference but rather with getting a more refined estimate of the population effect size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if we were expecting a population correlation between intelligence and job performance of around .50 a sample size of 20 will give us approximately 80% power alpha = .05 two tail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however in doing this study we are probably more interested in knowing whether the correlation is .30 or .60 or .50
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this context we would need a much larger sample size in order to reduce the confidence interval of our estimate to a range that is acceptable for our purposes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these and other considerations often result in the true but somewhat simplistic recommendation that when it comes to sample size more is better however huge sample sizes can lead to statistical tests becoming so powerful that the null hypothesis is always rejected for real data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is a problem in studies of differential item functioning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: funding agencies ethics boards and research review panels frequently request that a researcher perform a power analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the argument is that if a study is inadequately powered there is no point in completing the research
lines.name: Sundanese
